[[Paul Hodes]] (Co-Chair) | receipts = 670.7 | slogan = [[Image:Change We Can Believe In.svg]] | chant = Yes We Can | homepage = [http://www.barackobama.com/ www.barackobama.com] }} {{Barack Obama sidebar}} {{JoeBidenseries}} {{Wikinews|Barack Obama wins U.S. Presidency}} {{See also|United States presidential election, 2008}} [[Barack Obama]], then [[United States Senate#Seniority|junior]] United States [[United States Senate|Senator]] from [[Illinois]], announced his candidacy for [[President of the United States|the presidency of the United States]] in [[Springfield, Illinois]], on February 10, 2007."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/6349081.stm Obama Launches Presidential Bid]," [[BBC News]], February 10, 2007. Retrieved on January 14, 2008. [http://www.brightcove.tv/title.jsp?title=494649996&channel=353512430 Video] at Brightcove.TV. On August 27, 2008, he was declared nominee{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/28/us/politics/28DEMSDAY.html?hp |title=Obama Wins Nomination; Biden and Bill Clinton Rally Party - NYTimes.com |publisher=Nytimes.com |author=Adam Nagourney |date=Published: August 28, 2008 |accessdate=October 17, 2008}} of the [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic Party]] for the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 presidential election]]. He was the first [[African American]] in history to be nominated on a major party ticket.Jeff Zeleny, "[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/04/us/politics/04elect.html Obama Clinches Nomination; First Black Candidate to Lead a Major Party Ticket]," ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 4, 2008. Retrieved July 5, 2008. On August 23, 2008, Barack Obama's campaign announced that Senator [[Joe Biden]] of [[Delaware]] would be the Vice Presidential nominee.{{cite web|accessdate=August 28, 2008 |url=http://www.barackobama.com/index.php |title=Joe Biden! |publisher=BarackObama.com |quote="Breaking news: the text message is out and it's official... Barack Obama has selected Joe Biden to be his running mate!"}} On November 4, 2008, Obama won the election, making him the [[President-elect of the United States|President-elect]] and the first African American elected [[President of the United States]].{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/11/04/election.president/index.html|title=Barack Obama wins presidential election | work=[[CNN]] | date=November 4, 2008 | accessdate=November 5, 2008}}{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/05/us/politics/05campaign.html?_r=1&hp|title=Obama Wins Election|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=November 5, 2008 | first=Adam | last=Nagourney | date=November 5, 2008}} He is the third sitting Senator, after [[Warren G. Harding]] and [[John F. Kennedy]], to be elected President. His constitutional election to the office was completed with the meeting of the [[Electoral College (United States)|Electoral College]] on December 15, 2008, and the subsequent certification of the college's vote by the [[Joint session of the United States Congress|Joint Session]] of the [[United States Congress]] on January 8, 2009.{{cite news | first= Adam | last= Nagourney | coauthors= | title= Obama Wins Election | date= November 4, 2008 | publisher= | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/05/us/politics/05elect.html | work = New York Times | pages = | accessdate = November 5, 2008 }}{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title= Obama's Presidency | date= November 10, 2008 (Updated daily) | publisher= British Broadcasting Corporation | url = | work = BBC News | pages = | accessdate = November 10, 2008 }} Based on the results of the electoral vote count, Barack Obama was declared the elected [[President of the United States]] and Joseph Biden was declared officially as the elected [[Vice President of the United States]] in the 2008 presidential election.{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/28555802 |title=Congress meets to count electoral votes|date=January 8, 2009|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|accessdate=January 8, 2009}} ==Chronicle== Image:|A Hug in Unity, NH === End of the primaries === {{See|Barack Obama presidential primary campaign, 2008}} On June 3, 2008, after the [[Montana Democratic primary, 2008|Montana]] and [[South Dakota Democratic primary, 2008|South Dakota primaries]], Barack Obama secured enough delegates to clinch the nomination of the Democratic party for President of the United States. His opponent in the general election, [[United States Republican Party|Republican]] [[John McCain]], passed the delegate threshold to become the presumptive nominee of his party on March 4."[http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/03/04/march.4.gop/index.html McCain wins GOP nomination; Huckabee bows out]," [[CNN News]], March 5, 2008. Retrieved July 7, 2008; Simon Rushton, "[http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/05/29/gop.two/index.html McCain clinches Republican prize]," [[CNN News]], March 4, 2008. Retrieved July 7, 2008. On June 7, [[Hillary Rodham Clinton]], Obama's remaining opponent in the quest for the Democratic nomination, conceded defeat at the Democratic National Convention in Denver, Colorado and urged her supporters to back Obama.Sasha Issenberg, "[http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2008/06/08/clinton_ends_her_bid_hails_obama/ Clinton ends her bid, hails Obama]," ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', June 8, 2008. Retrieved July 5, 2008. See also: Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny, "[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/05/us/politics/05dems.html Clinton Ready to End Bid and Endorse Obama]," ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 5, 2008. Retrieved July 7, 2008. After a June 26 dinner at which Obama encouraged his fundraisers to donate to Clinton's debt-saddled campaign,Jeff Zeleny, "[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/27/us/politics/27campaign.html Obama Gives $2,300 for Clinton Debt]," ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 27, 2008. Retrieved July 7, 2008. Obama and Clinton ran their first post-primary event together in [[Unity, New Hampshire]] on June 27."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7477825.stm Clinton and Obama rally together]," [[BBC News]], June 27, 2008. Retrieved July 7, 2008; Mark Leibovich and Jeff Zeleny, "[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/28/us/politics/28obama.html Obama and Clinton Hold First Post-Primary Event]," ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 28, 2008. Retrieved July 7, 2008. Over the first two weeks of July, the campaign ran a heavier schedule of fundraising events, drawing from former donors to Clinton's campaign.Michael Luo and Christopher Drew, "[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/03/us/politics/03donate.html Obama Picks Up Fund-Raising Pace]," ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 3, 2008. Retrieved July 6, 2008. See also: "[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/07/05/AR2008070500779.html Obama, Clinton to hold joint fundraisers in NY]," [[Associated Press]], July 5, 2008. Retrieved July 7, 2008; Jonathan Weisman, "[http://blog.washingtonpost.com/the-trail/2008/07/05/obama_and_clinton_together_aga.html Obama and Clinton, Together Again]," ''[[Washington Post]]'', July 5, 2008. Retrieved July 7, 2008. Obama strategically had pictures made with financial experts Warren Buffett and Paul Volcker so the public would portray him having inside knowledge of Wall Street.[Alter, Jonathan, The Promise President Obama, Year One, Simon & Schuster, 2010,ISBN 978-1-4391-0119-3] ===Middle Eastern and European tour=== In July 2008 Obama traveled to [[Kuwait]], [[Afghanistan]],Carlotta Gall and Jeff Zeleny, "[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/20/us/politics/20OBAMA.htm Obama Opens a Foreign Tour in Afghanistan]," ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 20, 2008. [[Iraq]],Liz Sly, "[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-obama-iraq_sly_21jul21,0,7382906.story Obama arrives in Baghdad]," ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', July 21, 2008. Retrieved July 31, 2008. [[Jordan]],Mike Dorning, "[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-obama-jordanjul23,0,7718688.story Obama has press wondering what his real motives are]," ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', July 22, 2008. Retrieved July 31, 2008. the West Bank,Mike Dorning, "[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chi-obama-israel_dorning_24jul24,0,608506.story 'Friend of Israel' also woos Palestinians]," ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', July 24, 2008. Retrieved July 31, 2008. [[Israel]], [[Germany]], [[France]], and the [[United Kingdom]]. During the course of this trip he met with assorted international leaders, including President [[Hamid Karzai]] of [[Afghanistan]],Kim Barker, "[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-obama-afghan_barker_21jul21,0,3042624.story Obama, Karzai keep talk 'positive']," ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', July 21, 2008. Retrieved July 31, 2008; Elana Schor, "[http://www.guardian.co.uk/global/2008/jul/25/uselections2008.germany Obama arrives in Paris to meet Sarkozy]," ''[[The Guardian]]'', July 25, 2008. Retrieved July 31, 2008. On July 24, 2008 he gave a speech at the [[Berlin Victory Column|Victory Column]] in [[Berlin]] before a crowd of estimated 200,000 to 240,000 people.{{cite web | url = http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,567932,00.html | title = Obama's Berlin Speech: People of the World, Look at Me | accessdate = October 23, 2008| date = July 25, 2008 | publisher = Spiegel Online}} ===Saddleback Civil Forum=== {{Main|Civil Forum on the Presidency}} The Civil Forum on the Presidency was the venue of back-to-back interviews of U.S. presidential candidates John McCain and Barack Obama by pastor Rick Warren on August 16, 2008, at Saddleback Church in [[Lake Forest, California]]. ===Vice Presidential selection=== [[Image:Biden Obama.jpg|thumb|Joe Biden and Barack Obama after the presentation of Biden as the vice presidential running mate in Springfield, Illinois]] {{Main|Democratic Party (United States) vice presidential candidates, 2008|Joe Biden presidential campaign, 2008#ObamaâBiden campaign 2008}} Barack Obama's vice presidential running mate had been a subject of speculation since the end of the primaries. As of August 2008, some of the most popular choices for VP included, but were not limited to, Clinton, Biden, [[Indiana]] Senator [[Evan Bayh]], [[Kansas]] Governor [[Kathleen Sebelius]], [[Virginia]] Governor [[Tim Kaine]], retired General and former Secretary of State [[Colin Powell]], [[New Mexico]] Governor [[Bill Richardson]], and retired General [[Wesley Clark]]. [[Image:Obamas and Bidens.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Barack Obama]], [[Michelle Obama]], [[Jill Biden]] and [[Joe Biden]] at the [[United States Vice President]]ial announcement on August 23, 2008 in [[Springfield, Illinois]]]] {{Wikinews|Barack Obama chooses Senator Joe Biden as his Vice Presidential running mate for 2008}} On August 21, 2008, Obama announced that he had made a selection for the VP spot, but would not reveal until August 23 who it was.Mooney, Alexander (August 21, 2008). [http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/08/21/obama.vice.president/index.html "Obama: I've decided on my running mate"], ''[[CNN]]''. Retrieved July 9, 2010. Obama's campaign encouraged supporters to sign up for a [[text messaging]] system that would alert them the moment he announced his choice. On August 22, [[KMBC-TV|KMBC]] News of [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]] spotted bumper stickers of an Obama/Bayh '08 ticket that were being printed in [[Lenexa, Kansas]]. Three sources close to a local printing plant reported that such material was being produced.{{cite news|title=Bumper Sticker Could Indicate Bayh Is Obama's Veep|url=http://www.kmbc.com/politics/17267009/detail.html|publisher=KMBC News|date=August 22, 2008}} The image of the bumper sticker circulated on the internet. However, [[NBC News]] later quoted sources stating that Bayh had been informed by Obama's campaign that he was not the pick.{{cite news|title=Bayh, Kaine out of Obama's veep race|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/26336195/|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date=August 22, 2008}} According to an [[Associated Press]] report that same evening, [[Joe Biden]] was selected as Obama's candidate.{{cite news|title=Obama picks Biden for veep|url=http://www.vvdailypress.com/news/obama-8201-biden-presidential.html|work=[[Daily Press (California)|Daily Press]]|location=Victorville, California|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=August 25, 2008|accessdate=July 9, 2010}} The Associated Press report was confirmed several hours later, on August 23, on Barack Obama's official campaign website and by a mass [[Text messaging|text message]] to supporters.{{cite web|accessdate=August 23, 2008 |url=http://www.barackobama.com/index.php |title=Joe Biden! |publisher=BarackObama.com |quote="Breaking news: the text message is out and it's official... Barack Obama has selected Joe Biden to be his running mate!"}} Obama selected Biden to be vice president for three reasons: he could relate to blue-collar Americans (i.e. he is originally from Pennsylvaniaâarguably a blue-collar state); he has a multitude of connections on Capitol Hill; and he has more personal connections in foreign policy than Obama.{{cite book|last=Alter|first=Jonathan|title=The Promise President Obama, Year One|publisher=Simon & Schuster|year=2010|isbn=978-1-4391-0119-3}}> {{Clear}} ==Opinion polling== {{See|Nationwide opinion polling for the United States presidential election, 2008|Statewide opinion polling for the United States presidential election, 2008}} [[Image:McCainObamaMatchupTWINtop.svg|''frame''|300px|thumb|Statewide opinion polling for the 2008 United States presidential election up to November 3, 2008.States are colored according to the average from at least the last three poll results from [[Statewide opinion polling for the United States presidential election, 2008]]. Washington, D.C. is presumed heavy Democrat. If there have been more than 3 polls taken within a month of the latest poll, then these are averaged.
{{legend|#0000CD|>10% Obama lead}} {{legend|#1E90FF|4%â10% Obama lead}} {{legend|#ADD8E6|1%â4% Obama lead}} {{legend|#696969|Tie}} {{legend|#F08080|1%â4% McCain lead}} {{legend|#FF0000|4%â10% McCain lead}} {{legend|#B22222|>10% McCain lead}}
]] The day after Obama's acceptance speech at the [[Democratic National Convention]], Obama's [[U.S. Republican Party|Republican]] opponent, [[Arizona]] Senator [[John McCain]], announced his selection of [[Alaska]] Governor [[Sarah Palin]] as his running mate.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/08/29/palin.republican.vp.candidate/index.html|title=McCain taps Alaska Gov. Palin as vice president pick|publisher=CNN|date=August 29, 2008|accessdate=September 13, 2008}} Almost immediately, the Obama/Biden ticket plunged in the polls: in a [[The Gallup Organization|Gallup]] poll of likely voters, the McCain/Palin ticket gained a 10-point lead.{{cite news | first = Charlie | last = Cook | title = Time to Reassess the White House Race | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/26625240/ | publisher = [[MSNBC]] | date = September 9, 2008 | accessdate = September 13, 2008}} The erosion of support for the Obama/Biden ticket was especially pronounced among white women who had previous shown strong support for Hillary Clinton.{{cite news | first = Ewan | last = MacAskill | title = The Palin effect: white women now deserting Obama, says survey | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/lifeandstyle/2008/sep/10/women.uselections2008 | publisher = ''[[The Guardian]]'' | date = September 10, 2008 | accessdate = September 13, 2008 | location=London}} However, Obama regained and maintained the national poll average after September 19.[http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2008/president/us/general_election_mccain_vs_obama-225.html General Election: McCain vs. Obama], [[RealClearPolitics]]. Retrieved November 3, 2008. A [[RealClearPolitics]] average of 14 national polls taken between October 29 and November 2 shows an average 7.3% lead for Obama over McCain. Obama's highest support in the polling average was 8.2% on October 14. Among individual polls tracked by RealClearPolitics, Obama's highest support was recorded in a ''[[Newsweek]]'' poll conducted between June 18 and June 19 and a [[Pew Research]] poll conducted between October 23 and October 26 showing a 15% lead. [[The Gallup Organization|Gallup]] conducted weekly polls of registered voters to measure support among the candidates. The final poll conducted between October 27 and November 2 showed 24% of pure Independents supporting Obama, trailing the 32% who favored McCain. Obama's Independent support peaked at 33% the week of October 6-October 12.[http://www.gallup.com/poll/108049/Candidate-Support-Political-Party-Ideology.aspx Candidate Support by Political Party and Ideology] Retrieved November 3, 2008. A [[RealClearPolitics]] average of four national polls measuring favorable/unfavorable opinions taken between October 28 and November 2 shows an average 55.5% favorable rating and 39.8% unfavorable rating. Obama's highest ratings in the polling average were 61.2% favorable and 32.5% unfavorable on July 8.[http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2008/president/us/obama_favorableunfavorable-643.html Obama: Favorable/Unfavorable], [[RealClearPolitics]]. Retrieved November 3, 2008. As of November 3, 2008, one day before the election, the RealClearPolitics electoral map excluding toss up states shows 278 electoral votes for Obama/Biden, an electoral majority, and 132 electoral votes for opponents McCain/Palin.[http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/maps/obama_vs_mccain/?map=5 RealClearPolitics Electoral College: RealClear Electoral Count], [[RealClearPolitics]]. Retrieved November 3, 2008. Including toss up states, the Obama/Biden ticket leads with 338 votes.[http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/maps/obama_vs_mccain/?map=10 RealClearPolitics Electoral College: No Toss Up States], [[RealClearPolitics]]. Retrieved November 3, 2008. ==Political positions== {{Main|Political positions of Barack Obama|Comparison of United States presidential candidates, 2008}} Obama has taken positions on many national, political, economic and social issues, either through public comments or his senatorial voting record. Since announcing his presidential campaign in February 2007, Obama emphasized withdrawing American troops from Iraq, increasing [[Energy policy of the United States|energy independence]] (that includes [[New Energy For America]] plan{{cite web|url=http://www.barackobama.com/pdf/factsheet_energy_speech_080308.pdf |title=Microsoft Word - Fact Sheet Energy Speech 082508 FINAL.doc |date= |format=PDF |accessdate=October 17, 2008}}), decreasing the influence of [[Lobbying in the United States|lobbyists]], and promoting [[Universal health care#United States|universal health care]] as top national priorities. ==Fundraising== [[Image:President George W. Bush bipartisan economic meeting Congress, McCain, Obama.jpg|thumb|right|Obama (far right) participates in a bipartisan meeting with President Bush and Senator McCain, and House and Senate party leaders regarding the economy, September 25, 2008]] {{See also|Fundraising for the 2008 United States presidential election}} Barack Obama's fundraising has broken previous records for presidential primary and general campaigns, and has changed expectations for future presidential elections. The campaign avoided using public campaign funds, raising all of its money privately from individual donors. By the general election the campaign committee raised more than $650 million for itself, and coordinated with both the [[Democratic National Committee]] (DNC) and at least 18 state-level Democratic committees to create a joint-fundraising committee to raise and split tens of millions of dollars more. {{cite news | first= Helene | last= Cooper | coauthors= Jeff Zeleny | title= Obamaâs Transition Team Restricts Lobbyistsâ Role | date= November 11, 2008 | publisher= | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/12/us/politics/12obama.html | work = New York Times | pages = | accessdate = November 11, 2008 }} {{cite news | first= Michael| last= Luo| coauthors= | title= Obama Recasts the Fund-Raising Landscape |date=October 19, 2008| publisher= | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/20/us/politics/20donate.html | work = New York Times | pages = | accessdate=November 11, 2008}} {{cite news | first= Josh | last= Kurtz | coauthors= | title= Obama, DNC Set Up Fundraising Entity for States | date= | publisher= | url = http://www.rollcall.com/news/26789-1.html | work = Roll Call | pages = | accessdate = November 11, 2008}} Post-election fundraising continued for the separate transition administration, called the [[Obama-Biden Transition Project]], and also the separate inaugural ceremonies and celebrations committee. ===Chronology=== According to reports filed with the [[Federal Election Commission]], Obama's campaign raised more money in the first quarter of 2008 ($133,549,000) [http://query.nictusa.com/pres/2008/M2/C00431445.html Obama for America: Report of Receipts and Disbursements], [[Federal Election Commission]]. Retrieved April 3, 2008. than it had raised in all of 2007 ($103,802,537). The campaign had a relatively small total of $21.9 million in May, but went on to raise $52 million in June, after Obama had secured the nomination. Jeff Zeleny, "[http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/07/17/obama-raises-52-million-in-june/ Obama Raises $52 Million in June]," ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 17, 2008. Retrieved July 17, 2008. On June 19, Obama was the first major-party presidential candidate to turn down public financing for a general election campaign since the system was created in the aftermath of [[Watergate scandal|Watergate]].Jonathan D. Salant, "[http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601070&sid=aNi.G0PhWnFw&refer=home Obama Won't Accept Public Money in Election Campaign]," [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]], June 19, 2008. Retrieved June 19, 2008. Shailagh Murray and Perry Bacon Jr., "[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/06/19/AR2008061900914.html Obama to Reject Public Funds for Election]," ''[[Washington Post]]'', June 20, 2008. Retrieved June 19, 2008 Obama was expected to raise $265 million between the time of the announcement and election day. Ewen MacAskill, "[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/jun/20/barackobama.johnmccain US elections: Obama faces backlash for refusing public campaign funding]," ''[[The Guardian]]'', June 20, 2008. Retrieved June 21, 2008. By rejecting the funds in favor of private donations, the campaign was in a position to outspend John McCain prior to the election. Had he signed on to the plan, the campaign would only have been able to spend $84.1 million between the party convention in August and the general election in November. Emily Cadei, "[http://www.usatoday.com/news/politics/election2008/2008-06-19-opt-out-qa_N.htm Q & A: Obama's public funding opt-out]," ''[[USA Today]]'', June 20, 2008. Retrieved June 21, 2008. Obama explained his decision to opt out of the public financing system, saying, "public financing of presidential elections as it exists today is broken, and we face opponents who've become masters at gaming this broken system." Critics of the decision argued that the decision contradicted earlier statements that he would attempt to reach agreement with McCain to obtain public financing,Kenneth P. Vogel, "[http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0608/11217.html Obama move irks reform allies]," ''[[The Politico]]'', June 19, 2008. Retrieved June 21, 2008; Liz Sidoti, "[http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5ghb-cUeWpvC77LS_S8tI4aB7ENIQD91DVMOO0 With money, Obama to try to widen the battleground]," [[Associated Press]], June 20, 2008. Retrieved June 21, 2008. See also: Alan Silverleib, "[http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/06/20/obama.financing/index.html?iref=newssearch Analysis: Rejecting public funding won't hurt Obama]," [[CNN News]], June 20, 2008. Retrieved July 7, 2008. and asserted that Obama's campaign was receiving as much support from unregulated [[527 group]]s as McCain's. John Dickerson, "[http://www.slate.com/id/2194083/ The Flip-Flop Brothers]," ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', June 20, 2008. Retrieved June 21, 2008. On September 4, 2008, the Obama campaign announced they raised $10 million in the 24 hour period after Republican Vice Presidential nominee [[Sarah Palin]]'s acceptance speech. The RNC reported raising $1 million in the same period.{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/09/04/obama-raises-8-million-af_n_124023.html | publisher=The Huffington Post | title=Obama Raises $10 Million After Palin Speech | date=September 4, 2008 | author=Nico Pitney }} On October 19, 2008, Obama's campaign announced a record fundraising total of $150 million for September 2008. This exceeded the campaign's single-month record ($66 million) for August 2008.{{cite news | url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB122441294251948009.html?mod=googlenews_wsj | publisher=Wall Street Journal | date=October 19, 2008| title=Obama Takes in a Record $150 Million, But McCain Narrows Gap in Some Polls | last= Cooper| first= Christopher| coauthors=Meckler, Laura }} The campaign raised much of its cash in small donations over the internet, with about half of its intake coming in increments of less than $200.{{cite web | url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/162403 | title=Obamaâs âGood Willâ Hunting | author=Michael Isikoff | date=October 4, 2008 | publisher=Newsweek}} Both major party campaigns screened regularly for patterns of abuse and returned or rejected donations in excess of legal limits, from overseas, from untraceable addresses, or from fraudulent names.{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/politics/6078399.html|title=Online campaign donations spark new concerns of abuse|last=MOSK|first=MATTHEW|date=October 25, 2008|publisher=The Houston Chronicle|accessdate=October 26, 2008}} After some criticism of the Obama campaign on conservative blogs, the [[Republican National Committee]] asked the [[Federal Election Commission]] to investigate the Obama campaign's screening practices.{{cite news|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/njonline/no_20081024_9865.php|title=FEC Rules Leave Loopholes For Online Donation Data|last=Munro|first=Neil|date=October 24, 2008|work=National Journal|publisher=National Journal Group Inc.|accessdate=October 26, 2008}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ==Media campaign== ===Innovations=== Barack Obama was particularly noted for his use of the [[Internet]] to rally supporters and make his policies known. "The integration of technology into the process of field organizing â¦ is the success of the Obama campaign," says Sanford Dickert, who worked as [[John Kerry]]âs chief technology officer for the [[United States presidential election|2004 campaign]]. "But the use of technology was not the end-all and be-all in this cycle. Technology has been a partner, an enabler for the Obama campaign, bringing the efficiencies of the internet into the real-world problems of organizing people in a distributed, trusted fashion."Stirland,S.:[http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2008/10/obamas-secret-w/],"Obama's Secret Weapons: Internet, Databases and Psychology", October 29, 2008. Retrieved on May 28, 2009. Obamaâs use of the Internet targeted 18 to 29 years olds, the age group most reliant on new media for political information about the election. Numbers have shown that presidential candidates have increased their presence and activity online. Obamaâs campaign managers understood that the reason younger voters tended to ignore politicians was because politicians tended to ignore issues which most concerned them, which is why Obama received such a positive reaction from Americaâs youth. Through forums and social websites such as [[MySpace]] and [[Facebook]], Obama built relationships with his supporters, and would-be supporters. He developed an upfront, personable and face-to-face quality that gave his supporters a sense of security and trust, which inspired them to rally others in their local communities. The supporters of Obama themselves formed a nation-wide community. The Internet provided useful and effective tools, such as the Neighbor-to-Neighbor tool on (My.BarackObama.com), allowing them to reach a large number of people in a short time in their own community, which in turn led to campaign rallying for more Obama support. Online communication led to Obama supporters engaging in social activities such as signmaking and door-to-door petitioning for Obama support, as well as simply discussing their opinions about policies and issues they supported along with Obama.Xenos,M. and W. Lance Bennett."THE DISCONNECTION IN ONLINE POLITICS: The Youth Political Sphere and US Election Sites, 2002-2004." Information, Communication, and Society 10 (2007): 443-64.Pasek, Josh, Daniel Romer, and Kathleen Hall Jamieson. "America's Youth and Community Engagement: How Use of Mass Media Is Related to Civic Activity and Political Awareness in 14-to-22-Year-Olds." Communication Research 33 (2006): 115-35. The Obama web campaign used consumer marketing to target individuals with customized information to their predicted interests. Political communication to viewers was based on data collected about them. This data was collected by volunteers, surveys on the website and records of consumption habits. Website surveys took a short amount of time to fill out.{{cite web | url=http://salon.com/news/feature/2008/07/16/obama_data | title=Barack Obama's super marketing machine | author=Mike Madden | date=July 16, 2008 | publisher=Salon.com}} More detailed surveys were requested and received through email. Records of consumption habits helped the campaign make predictions about people based on statistical models. People received messages tailored close to their beliefs. Marketing based on consumer data also enabled effective grassroots organizing through the website. Data gathered from the website indicated who the most dedicated constituents were; the website tracked how often a person visited and when. The campaign team then targeted and encouraged activists in contested, winnable areas, such as through the website program Neighbor-to-neighbor. All of his policies were made available online, and updates were sent to the subscribers of his political party via [[email]] and [[Text messaging|text message]], ultimately making him the most technologically savvy candidate to date, increasing his popularity among youth voters. An unprecedented communication strategy was the "online call toolâ. Over one million calls were made from residential, personal laptops and desktops. Obamaâs campaign was further strengthened by his opponent [[John McCain]]âs comparatively limited use of the Internet. McCain did not have the organization of Obamaâs campaign, nor did he spend a comparable amount of money on this portion of the campaign. Both opportune timing and usage of online campaigning gave Obama significant advantage over McCain. ===Logo=== {{See also|Obama logo}} Obama's campaign is notable for its extensive use of a [[logo]]. The logo, consisting of a circle, with the center suggesting a sun rising over fields in the colors of the [[Flag of the United States|American flag]], was designed by a team at Chicago design firm [[Sender LLC]]. "We were looking at the âoâ of his name and had the idea of a [[Sunrise|rising sun]] and a new day,â according to [[Sol Sender]], now a strategist at [[VSA Partners]]. "The sun rising over the horizon intended to evoked a new sense of hope."{{cite news |title=Chicago designers create Obama's logo | url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/cgi-bin/news.pl?id=23974&seenIt=1 |publisher=[[Chicago Business]] |date=February 22, 2007 |accessdate=December 14, 2008 }}{{cite web | url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/cgi-bin/news.pl?id=23974 | title=Chicago designers create Obama's logo | author=Lorene Yue and Brandon Glenn | publisher=[[Crain's Chicago Business]] | date=February 22, 2007 | accessdate=August 23, 2008}} ===Slogan=== Obama's campaign used the slogan "Change we can believe in" and the chant "Yes We Can". As with the presidential debates, no third party or independent candidates were offered an invitation. *Vice presidential debate was held on Thursday, October 2, 2008 at [[Washington University]], [[St. Louis, Missouri]]. ==Eve of the election== After campaigning at the Battle of Bull Run (Manassas, VA) on November 3, 2008, Barack Obama told David Axelrod (Chief Strategist), âI think weâre going to win, but if we donât Iâll be at peace. Weâve run as good a campaign as you could run, and if it isnât there, it isnât there.â ==Election day== On November 4, 2008, Barack Obama became the first [[African American]] to be elected President of the United States, sparking many celebrations in the United States and around the world. He gained almost 53% of the popular vote and 365 electoral votes. The popular vote percentage was the best showing for any presidential candidate since [[George H.W. Bush]] in 1988. His 365 electoral votes was the best showing since [[Bill Clinton]] had 379 in 1996. He won Colorado, Nevada, Virginia, Indiana, Florida, Ohio, and North Carolina, all states that were won by President [[George W. Bush]] in 2004. In addition, he became the first Democratic candidate to win one of Nebraska's electoral votes since the state decided to split their electoral votes. He was the first candidate to be elected President without winning Missouri since 1956. Obama also received more total votes than any Presidential candidate in history, totaling well over 69 million votes. 63% of Americans who met the voting requirements voted, the highest percentage in fifty years. Obama won the moderate vote 60â39 and the independent vote 52â44. Joe Biden also made history by becoming the first Roman Catholic to be elected Vice President. In addition, he is the longest-serving Senator to become Vice President, having served in the United States Senate for the 36 years prior to the election. Biden also won reelection to the Senate, but served only briefly in the 111th Congress before resigning to take his place as vice president. ==Certification of the electoral votes== On January 8, 2009, the [[Joint session of the United States Congress|joint session of the U.S. Congress]], chaired by former [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Dick Cheney|Cheney]] as [[President of the United States Senate|President of the Senate]] and Nancy Pelosi as [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]], announced and certified the votes of the [[Electoral College (United States)|Electoral College]] for the 2008 presidential election. From the electoral votes of the [[U.S. state#List of states|50 states]] and the [[District of Columbia]], Vice President Cheney declared 365 electoral votes for both Barack Obama of the state of [[Illinois]] and [[Joe Biden|Joseph Biden]] of the state of [[Delaware]] and 173 electoral votes for both [[John McCain]] of the state of [[Arizona]] and [[Sarah Palin]] of the state of [[Alaska]]. Based on the results of the electoral vote count, Vice President Cheney declared officially that Obama was elected as President of the United States and Biden was elected as Vice President of the United States.
